results.title: Fred's Films. ARC Cement Works Geelong [excerpt]
results.brief_description: The A.R.C Cement Works, Geelong, in the early 1960s is faithfully captured here by Fred Daley, steam train enthusiast and 8mm home movie maker. Fred has recorded a moment in industry that - post 2000 - no longer exists, that of the use of powerful steam locomotives. With the ‘loco’ pulling people on this occasion and not cement, this is most likely a farewell celebration to the use of the engines at the Plant. Fred’s titles tell us it is “3ft 6 Gauge” and there is a close up on an engine name-plate indicating this engine had come all the way from Manchester and another “1903 Leeds, Hudswell Clarke & Co Ltd No. 646”, a smaller black engine that had obviously been a working machine at the Cement Works for many a year. There is a sense of this being quite an occasion with many people visiting to take pictures and enjoy the plumes of steam from these majestic work horses.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is more whimsical in approach than the family based footage seen in other films, as reflected by the title ‘Open Road Open Sky’. In the opening scene we see Kenneth a fellow traveller wandering along country roads as well as shots of roads into the distance and the skies overhead. Further into the reel we see the Sherbrooke Forest, the ‘Burnham Beeches’ and ‘Alfred Nicholson Memorial Gardens’. There are shots of several animals such as emu and echidna as well as quite a bit of birdlife and Kenneth’s favourite shots of flowers and trees. The reel ends with Kenneth walking away from the forests and an end title shot.

Selected sequence list:

00:00:27:00 title ‘Open Road Open Sky’, Kenneth and a fellow traveller wandering along country roads.

00:01:00:00 large power poles along country roads, a few examples of country houses.

00:01:47:00 kangaroos and peacocks.

00:02:45:00 Kenneth walks along a road with his camera.

00:03:14:00 an emu, echidna and a wallaby come into view.

00:04:15:00 close up of Kenneth filming behind his camera followed by ‘Burnham Beeches’ mansion and estate in Sherbrooke Forest and the ‘Alfred Nicholson Memorial Gardens’.

00:06:31:00 birdlife inlcuding storks and lyrebirds.

00:07:44:00 Indigenous rider on horseback, waving at the camera whilst he rounds up horses, camels and Shetland ponies on grassland.

00:08:07:00 brolgas (filmed only from neck down only so difficult to be certain).

00:10:03:00 a quick shot of a woman behind the camera.

results.title: Fred's Films. 'Tis Christmas
results.brief_description: Captured here by Fred Daley, steam train enthusiast and 8mm home movie maker are highlights of a Melbourne family during the mid 1960s. Christmas for Fred included showing the trains of Flinders St and a W-Class Tram in the City of Melbourne, along with the famous ‘Foy’s Corner’, corner of Bourke and Swanston St. There are some amusements in the gardens and some ‘Viking’ boats rowing on the Yarra. A Santa in the back of a truck can only mean the office Christmas party. The family relax at a swimming pool and have a picnic in a bush setting. Back to a brief sequence of a helicopter landing on the helipad on the Yarra River, then there is a road trip. This features some impressive footage from the camera mounted on the car, to the Mornington Peninsula and Rosebud. Fred and the family relax staying at a caravan park at the beach, go water skiing, spend time in paddle boats and sand dune frolicking. A highlight is the joy flight taken over the area. Returning to the city, the family enjoy a sunny day at ‘Luna Park’ with the wonderful rides and amusements on offer. Fred’s camera work on the ‘Scenic Railway’ in particular, shows his steady hand.

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

This film is mostly focused on the Snowy Mountains Scheme in New South Wales, an integrated water and hydro-electric power utility constructed between 1949 and 1974, located in Australia’s Southern Alps.

There are also some scenes of travel around Brisbane in Queensland.

Frequent title cards assist the viewer with detail, particularly regarding the workings of the hydro Scheme.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 title ‘Snowy Mountain Scheme 1957’
00:00:22:00 the Snowy Mountain Authority buildings
00:00:44:00 title card ‘Guthega Dam’ followed by views of the dam
00:01:45:00 views of the accommodation buildings
00:02:00:00 title card ‘Guthega Power Station’
00:02:14:00 several views of a large cement pipeline
00:02:55:00 title card ‘Island Bend’
00:03:11:00 a four wheel drive vehicle at the site
00:03:19:00 a Pioneer Express bus waiting for passengers
00:03:22:00 sign ‘Snowy Mountain Lookout’ followed by wide vistas of the mountains
00:03:44:00 title card ‘Adaminaby Dam’
00:04:03:00 trucks working in a quarry and the clearance of trees for the workings of the Scheme
00:04:50:00 workers atop a tower construction
00:05:15:00 sign for the contractors, ‘Etudes Et Enterprises’ at the T.I. power station
00:05:31:00 title card ‘Tumut Ponds’
00:05:48:00 mouths of tunnels into the mountainsides
00:06:27:00 title card ‘Cabramurra’
00:07:41:00 title card ‘Cooma Airport’
00:07:45:00 airplane for Butler Air Transport
00:08:14:00 title card ‘Queensland 1957’
00:08:19:00 Brisbane City Hall
00:08:50:00 title card ‘Mt Coot-Tha’
00:09:14:00 title card ‘Brisbane River’, followed by views of the river
00:09:55:00 ‘Koalas at Lone Pine’ followed by a koala sitting on a dog’s back, and kangaroos
00:10:35:00 ‘Glasshouse Mountains’
00:11:00:00 ‘Long Island’ and a map of the coast of Queensland showing the location
00:11:20:00 beach scenes and an open four wheel drive modified to take passengers from small boats to the shore and on to the holiday huts
00:12:24:00 fishing scenes and wooden boxes full of fish
00:12:40:00 title card ‘Visit to South Molle’
00:13:57:00 title card ‘Visit to Happy Bay’ followed by views around the beach and bay area
00:16:08:00 title card ‘Departure of Guests’ and the holiday visitors are taken on the modified jeep to a small boat, bound for the ferry

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 3 focuses on the day the Queen and Duke arrived in Melbourne, and consists mainly of short sections of footage, much of which is also seen in other Reels of this Collection.

Detailed Description Reel 3:

Opens with aerial view of motorcade at top of Bourke Street, Melbourne, (probably leaving Parliament House). At 00:00:11:00 footage switches to Essendon Airport, with officials and police arriving in car and on motorbikes: 00:00:31:00 Crowds are seen waiting for the Queen’s arrival. 00:00:41:00 Arrival of Victorian Governor Sir Dallas Brooks. 00:00:50:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band. 00:01:07:00 footage of crowds along streets from moving car. 00:01:12:00 Queen and Duke walking across tarmac at Essendon Airport. 00:01:20:00 photographers filming the crowds from a moving car. 00:01:24:00 back at Essendon Airport, assembled sailors. 00:01:30:00 close-ups of various officials at, and leaving, Airport. 00:02:25:00 Queen and Duke exiting aeroplane. 00:02:34:00 Queen and Duke reviewing assembled sailors. 00:02:55:00 Queen and Duke in car beginning to leave airport, crowds running to view car. 00:03:07:00 close-up of luggage. 00:03:10:00 staff exiting plane. 00:03:35:00 drive past Essendon Town Hall with crowds on balcony of Town Hall and lining streets. 00:04:00:00 Crowds in street. 00:04:11:00 Queen and Duke on dais, Mayor making a speech. 00:05:08:00 street scene (probably in Essendon), with large crowd in process of dispersing. 00:05:18:00 cars leaving Essendon Town Hall. 00:05:35:00 crowd on steps of State Parliament shot from moving car. 00:05:51:00 crowds behind barriers lining CBD streets. 00:06:12:00 close-up of Henry Bolte, then leader of the Opposition Victorian Liberal Party, on street outside Parliament House. 00:06:27:00 close-up of Queen and Duke getting into car. 00:06:54:00 close-up of people in crowd with spires of St Patrick’s Cathedral in background. 00:07:37:00 State Parliament building, assembled police. 00:07:41:00 people watching from the top of the Imperial Hotel (still extant on the corner Bourke and Spring Streets, Melbourne), and a “Molina’s” sign can be seen (indicating Melbourne’s famous Molina’s Cafe). 00:07:49:00 close-up of workman affixing red carpet to steps of State Parliament; results.description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 3 focuses on the day the Queen and Duke arrived in Melbourne, and consists mainly of short sections of footage, much of which is also seen in other Reels of this Collection.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 57]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film captures a trip on the ‘Paddle Steamer Emmylou’ along the Murray River, NSW and Victoria, in 1982.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 Jess Gadsden and companions having lunch on the deck of the ‘Emmylou’
00:00:28:00 houses appear on on the riverbank
00:03:13:00 the ‘Emmylou’ flag being explained to passengers
00:03:14:00 buffet 1970s style
00:03:55:00 ‘Paddle Steamer Emmylou’ in full view
00:14:41:00 Jess Gadsden standing on the bank, looking at a weir on the Murray and waving at the camera
00:09:38:00 passengers assisting with loading wood onto the ‘Emmylou’

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

In this film, we spend time around a bay that is probably Port Phillip in Melbourne. Scenes are filmed on the piers and from the piers, capturing all the activity. There are lovely scenes of yachts sailing, people watching boat races, adults and children fishing and dockside workers undertaking their jobs on the piers.

The film also contains wonderful scenes of the celebration parade for the ‘Centenary of Essendon Municipal Government’ from 1961.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a large ship
00:00:20:00 yachts on the bay with a pier in the foreground
00:01:03:00 a large 3-sail yacht tacking in the bay
00:01:19:00 a fishing rod in the foreground
00:01:20:00 children and adults fishing off the pier
00:01:28:00 men working with a tractor and pulley on the pier
00:02:02:00 pulleys being operated to take up large chains and an anchor on a pier
00:02:57:00 closer up to some yachts
00:02:05:00 motor boats on the bay
00:03:50:00 large yacht and passengers close up
00:04:07:00 a military ship
00:04:26:00 yachts racing on the bay
00:04:42:00 an older man, wearing a classic 1940s – 1950s style hat, standing on the pier looking out across the bay
00:05:00:00 a boy wearing rolled up trousers, fishing off the pier and more lovely yachts sailing by before we see a man and another boy who is lying down on the pier alongside his fishing rod
00:05:34:00 a motor boat goes by
00:05:42:00 a young man rowing a small rowboat
00:06:12:00 women wearing wide floral skirts, sitting on beach chairs on the pier, boys fishing and a bicycle
00:06:19:00 a tugboats travels past the pier
00:06:25:00 small cars on the pier
00:06:46:00 a large ship sails into the bay
00:06:55:00 two young boys collect a wicker fishing basket and rods
00:07:24:00 large passenger ship sails close by the end of the pier where some small cars are parked
00:07:40:00 seagulls flying by
00:07:46:00 program for the ‘Centenary of Municipal Government in Essendon 1861 – 1961, official Centennial Celebration program. Saturday December 9’
00:08:00:00 a military band leads a street parade
00:08:20:00 Australian Army members march by
00:08:30:00 various ‘floats’ as well as ‘marching girls’ go by in the celebratory parade
00:08:52:00 the Girl Guides ‘World Wide Friendship’ ‘float’ goes by followed by the Essendon Football Club
00:09:25:00 the Australian Navy contingent goes by, followed by the Victorian Railways ‘float’ showing off a train carriage and a bagpipes band in full regalia
00:10:00:00 – 00:11:15:00 participants in the parade include communities dressed in traditional costumes, the local library, more marching girls, local business and associations and schools, veterans groups and the RSL, a ‘supermarket float’ and a group of horse riders
00:11:33:00 the ‘Bowmen of Essendon’ go by followed by an ‘Australian made’ stilt walker, Christmas ‘floats’ and the Scouts
00:12:05:00 the Australian Air Force, a glimpse of some walking ‘briquettes’ and some girls who might be a netball team or school group
00:12:15:00 young women modelling smart outfits of the day including hats and gloves being driven in a sports car followed by a ‘float’ for a local ‘dance hall’
00:12:45:00 ‘Home Pride Bread horse drawn van goes by with decorations and a young woman ‘baker’, followed by a giant paint tin ‘float’
00:12:53:00 a car and boat accompanied by ‘sea scouts’
00:13:07:00 ‘Essendon Brass Band’ marches by followed by the Ukraine community group in costumes and a local hospital or medical group
00:13:19:00 handmade card for ‘Essendon 1961’

results.title: Fred's Films. Stepping South: Apollo Bay Jan 1963
results.brief_description:
It’s summer 1963, time to pack up the car and head to the beach. Fred Daley, steam train enthusiast and 8mm home movie maker, follows his family’s trip to the beaches of Apollo Bay, the lush rain forest of Paradise and the powerful beauty of the Twelve Apostles.
Along the way we also see Lorne, Port Campbell and Cinema Point in the Otway Ranges.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 1 of this extraordinary collection corresponds to the first 11 minutes of the official State Film Centre release (see ACMI Collection Title [315392]) “The Visit to Victoria of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh”. It shows some of the preparations for the visit, the arrival by plane of the royal couple at Essendon Airport and their first progress through Melbourne to State Parliament and Government House. We see the Queen opening State Parliament, visiting the MCG to meet with Australian armed servicemen and women, attending a special race meeting at Flemington Racecourse and a Davis Cup game at Kooyong Tennis Centre. The Queen and Duke also go to St Paul’s Cathedral, and the reel closes with the official dedication of the forecourt and eternal flame at Melbourne’s Shrine of Remembrance.

Detailed Description Reel 1:

Opens with Titles:
1) “The State Film Centre Presents”
2) “The Visit to Victoria of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh”
3) “Filmed with the co-operation of State Government Departments, Cine Service Pty. Ltd., and The Films Advisory Bureau”
00:00:42:00. Followed by shot of exterior of Geological Museum (this building at 55 McArthur St East Melbourne, used as the Government offices for the Royal Visit; was demolished 1964), and footage of the State Director and staff at work.
00:00:59:00 footage of street scenes and close-ups of decorated buildings in Melbourne CBD (moving diorama of kangaroo and emu above The Myer Emporium 00:01:09:0 to 00:01:16:0).
00:01:27 Essendon Airport awaiting the arrival of the royal visitors.
00:01:38:00 close up of then Governor Dallas Brooks; John Cain Snr (then Premier) also present.
00:01:40:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band.
00:01:50:00 plane lands.
00:02:03:00 Queen & Duke exit plane and are greeted by Governor and Premier on tarmac.
00:02:23:00 Queen reviews guard of honour provided by troops from Royal Australian Navy.
00:02:39:00 Queen & Duke are introduced to a succession of “leading citizens”.
00:03:02:00 car begins departure from airport, and drives through crowd-lined streets.
00:03:24:00 car arrives at Parliament House, Melbourne, where a crowd fills the front steps.
00:03:33:00 Queen and Duke stand halfway up steps and are flanked by Victorian Parliamentary Mace and Black Rod (probably being held by Serjeant-at-Arms and Usher of the Black Rod).
00:03:40:00 Royal Salute - 4 gun artillery salute fired in Domain.
00:03:42:00 Queen and Duke descend steps of Parliament House, Melbourne.
00:03:46:00 drives through crowd-lined streets of Melbourne CBD, with Queen & Duke waving and smiling at crowds.
00:03:52:00 aerial shot of Collins Street at Spring Street end.
00:04:24:00 aerial shot of corner of Swanston and Flinders Streets (site of future Gas and Fuel buildings and Federation Square).
00:04:27:00 an aerial shot looking back to CBD from St Kilda Rd; Flinders St Station and St Paul’s Cathedral can be identified.
00:04:31:00 aerial distance shot of Government House, Melbourne.
00:04:42:00 car arrives at Government House.
00:05:04:00 shot of Royal Standard flying over Government House (only flown when monarch in residence).
00:05:08 night scenes of Melbourne CBD decorations.
00:05:28:00 night scenes of fireworks.
00:05:36:00 Queen & Duke taking places at opening of Victorian Parliament; footage inside Legislative Council chamber, Queen in state dress and Order of Garter (Duke in uniform).
00:07:42:00 the M.C.G, and an assembly of ex-servicemen and women.
00:08:02:00 shot of airplane in mid-air. 00:08:08:00 children waving flags in crowd.
00:08:13:00 close-up of Queen making speech (into microphone).
00:08:18:00 close-up of technicians broadcasting the speech.
00:08:24:00 Flemington Racecourse, aerial shot of crowd and betting gates.
00:08:36:00 Queen & Dukes’ car arrives, driving down middle of course.
00:08:52:00 horses in saddling paddock. 00:09:01:00 horses racing.
00:09:17:00 Queen presents cup to winning owner & talks to winning jockey.
00:09:25:00 Queen takes her seat in the stands at Kooyong Tennis Centre.
00:09:32:00 tennis being played.
00:09:44:00 shot of film camera operators (possibly filming newsreel footage?).
00:09:46:00 a presentation is made to Queen on the court.
00:09:51:00 shot of exterior of St Paul’s Cathedral (Melbourne), Queen & Duke walk down steps with Archbishop of Melbourne (Joseph Booth).
00:10:02:00 aerial shots of car driving through Melbourne streets.
00:10:05:00 aerial view of Shrine of Remembrance.
00:10:09:00 close-up of Queen making speech at microphone.
00:10:29:00 close-up of Duke listening to speech.
00:10:36:00 aerial shots of listening crowd.
00:11:24:00 Queen pushes some mechanism near microphone, and the Shrine’s eternal flame is seen smoking (as the Queen has just lighted it.)

results.title: Fred's Films. Our Family [excerpt]
results.brief_description: Fred Daley, steam train enthusiast and 8mm home movie maker, follows his family’s trip into the City of Melbourne. Starting out at St. Kilda Road, they go on into town to sample coffee and sandwiches al fresco-style before journeying on to an exciting game of Australian Rules football at the MCG (Geelong vs. Hawthorn Grand Final 1963). The family meanders around the fountain at the Southern Cross hotel and ventures to Cook’s Cottage in the picturesque Fitzroy Gardens. They finish up the relaxing day with a cold beverage in the beer garden of the Chevron Hotel.
